5718qS8px0xrWM2a0C5stg.text: Pretty decent tapas at very reasonable prices. the best dishes are the lamb skewer, the patatas bravas and the tortilla. it's not the best tapas in the world, there are better places in london, but it's up there.

cgCkHQv0f01udn7t9A1Tbw.text: Great tapas spot in Fitzrovia.  Croquets, chorizo, and the seafood tapas were our highlights.  Prices are reasonable for what you get, although the Sangria is a bit on the high side (£20).  Very friendly service.  Reservations are a must.

TXDhqLZHEYy8aKK-FDGjzw.text: Wonderful tapas / Spanish restaurant in Charlotte Street. They really go all the way to make it feel Spanish - wooden floors/bars, tiled walls and masses of Spanish country pottery and ceramics in every nook and cranny. It could risk being over the top, but with Spanish staff and most of all great, authentic tapas Navarro's carries it all off with style. We had octopus (delicious), chicken on a skewer (light and tangy), croquetas and (of course) great patatas bravs in a zingy sauce. All washed down with decent, properly prepared sangria. Marvellous. The restaurant is larger than it looks from the outside and, in contrast to many, the basement section is juts as atmospheric and lively as the main room upstairs. Thoroughly recommended for all lovers of things Spanish.

qdNZzyb1Zp_SguI7Lvu6kA.text: I suppose this is a good restaurant if you never been in spain or ever eaten in a spanish restaurant. If it is not your case dont go. Waiters are nice and intention is good but it is too cliche (the way they dress and the decorztion) . Dishes are typic but not good (berenjenas were gross) , pulpo tasted weird and cheese was a joke (plus bread wasnt good). Cjampinoes were really good .

awkjBW_hQefvwypzuSwKsw.text: The food is amazing, the service a little less so, and the decor  well, you just wouldn't. But it's really only the food that matters.

u14FoXUXJgZw_4k_KwcUqw.text: Went for a Christmas party: atmosphere was great, service was friendly and food was delicious. Get the skewers!

yP4l8E0K9leZ7kuWKxCYKA.text: My fave place in Fitzrovia. A regular and happy

8GnWO4CbGGPizwlGDAjzwg.text: Not as good as Salt Yard around the corner on Goodge Street but good, fun, yummy, cozy and peaceful atmosphere -- would definitely return

fm1WKpjmcUiWikror8LVaw.text: Pretty decent tapas. However, we were a large party and therefore went for the set menu at 20 quid a head, and I'm not sure that what I ate ended up being worth it. It felt like sometimes there wasn't quite enough of each dish, so you ended up with a plate full of tiny bites. It was also difficult to get enough tap water and bread for the table. This place might be better if you don't go with large groups.

t74FQQ-J2OIA1EYGt60jUA.text: The food weren't too bad. Some of the tapas were pretty good. Some tasted like airplane food though. And the service was pretty bad. I waited 30 mins before I walked up to the bar to get the waiter's attention and get the bill.. I tipped them 1p, which resulted in them asking me a lot of awkward questions. I live just around the corner, but I'll never go back...

dDepoN6MP9eguRcddbnsbw.text: Was last in Navarro's in late January 2011. Lovely place, staff are very personable and helpful with interpreting the dishes and our waitress advised on what might be best when we were stuck. The dishes are delicious and because there is such variety it is quite a thrill to dine there as the food does excite the taste buds. The decor and seating is great, though please note if going there for the first time there is the odd one or two areas where you may need to 'mind the step'. It feels very authentically Spanish and for an hour or two one can feel on holiday in Spain. I can thoroughly recommend it.

sHxVVYMEg7YAEU24xtO07w.text: Navarro's, a small and atmospheric restaurant on Charlotte street, serves a wide-range of traditional hispanic cuisine at reasonable prices. It's not cheap, but you definately get what you pay for here. The staff are native spanish speakers, and wear traditional costume which surprisingly adds an air of authenticity rather than tackiness. A great place for both dates and larger groups,and certainly the best spanish restaurant i've found in town.

L-vvz2a_xd5A7uj_Gd9niQ.text: LOVE THIS PLACE! I've been now a few times - for team lunches as well as dinner dates with friends and I've found that whether in a group of 7 or 2 - you get a great meal, awesome service, and spot-on wine pairing.  Ambiance: Walking in, you feel like you are transported out of London and into a classy tapa house in Spain.  Clearly, a lot of thought was put into the interior, from the tables all the way town to the tiled walls.  During a recent dinner here I was only hoping the food didn't come out so fast.  It was hard to resist dipping into everything all at once when the evening could have gone on for hours.Wine - Let the servers know which food you are most looking forward to and you'll be suggested a pairing that is both affordable and delicious.  On my last dinner outting, we had the Barbera - which was great with the meatballs, calamari and richer dishes.Tapas - There is nothing else to say then they were all SO good. Fish, meat, potatoes - each provides a decent portion for 2-3 to share, and as always with tapas you don't have to be in the mood for just one thing. During my last dinner for two we ordered about 7 all together, which was probably too much but over a bottle of wine we were able to enjoy them over the course of the evening slowly.If in the Goodge Street/Charlotte Street area, don't miss out.

SJr1P2WaDwNhf-sd5SDXxw.text: Despite some 3 stars reviews, my fiance & I loved this place.It is not a michelin star restaurant and so it won't produce michelin star food. What it offers are home made tapas. It feels like what your parents would cook.Good size portion and great customer services from the staff. Smiles all around.As others mentioned, it looks empty from the outside but once we stepped in, it was pretty busy. There are seating downstairs and were lucky to have a table on a Saturday night without a reservation.I love the décor... very humble and nothing too fancy. The ambience was nice too and we didn't have to shout across to each other to have a conversation.The menu was pretty small which I thought was a good idea because they would be cooking what they're good at. We ordered 6 tapas between the 2 of us and shared a dessert. We were pretty stuffed and were satisfied with the food.We had the stuff aubergine, patatas bravas, bacalao, calamari, chicken with prawns and corquette with ham. Dessert was churros. All were up to our expectation apart from the calamari. The batter could do with a bit of seasoning.I have been to Iberica and Barrafina on numerous occasions. I love both with a passion and have fallen in love with them. However you cannot compare them to Navarros. They are so different to each other yet I'd recommend to try both out.We will be returning.

6rTg9mJhHtFgPSuy6OV4-w.text: I had a nice leisurely dinner at Navarro's with Matt B. and a couple of friends we hadn't seen in a while.  We walked in right when they opened and were seated on the top floor, with the caveat that we would have to be out by nine for another party.  I liked the dim, cozy atmosphere of the place - it was ideal for catching up with friends.  The food ranged from average to great, and we enjoyed two bottles of the tasty, affordable house red.  Service was decent, with a forgotten dish but no real issues.  Our waitress was friendly and reasonably helpful.Bread and olive oil cost 95 pence per person.  I thought this was pretty miserly, but as Matt needs his carbs, he got some.  It was decent, but no better than the free stuff.  Our group of four ordered a mix of shared and individual plates ranging from £4.60 to £10.95, and some of which were delicious.My favorite of the bunch was the simplest and cheapest - sardinas a la plancha, or fresh grilled sardines with oil and lemon.  If you're creeped out by the idea of eating whole animals, avoid this one, as they are whole sardines.  Delicious, flavorful whole sardines with oily flesh wonderfully seasoned.I also enjoyed the Spanish tortilla, a fluffy omelet made with diced potato, egg, and onion.  I've had better versions, but it was still tasty.  The dish I ordered that didn't come was the lentils with chorizo, but I did try the lentils with garbanzos.  The vegetarian version was inexplicably more expensive, but it was a good dish.  The stewed lentils and chickpeas were hearty and full of flavor.  I also liked the bacalao a la roteña, a dish of pan-fried cod simmered with onions, peppers, and tomatoes.  The fish was nice and buttery, as cod tends to be, and I enjoyed the chunky vegetable sauce.  Another winner were the gambas al ajillo - shelled prawns in a garlic, chilli, and wine sauce.  The prawns had good texture and they were very spicy, in a good way.The rest of our tapas I found rather mediocre.  A cheese and charcuterie board, the most expensive item at £10.95, was not very memorable.  It was a fair selection of meat, with Serrano ham, salchichón, and chorizo, but there was only one kind of cheese that went unnamed.  Nothing stood out.  Pulpo a la gallega was disappointing.  This was a dish of Galician style octopus served with sliced potatoes and seasoned with pimentón, sea salt, and olive oil.  The flavors were all there, but the octopus itself was a bit slimy and didn't have enough bite.  Skewers of grilled scallop and chorizo were unappealing.  The scallop was served with its roe, and the way it was prepared was pretty unappealing.  The chorizo was good, but the scallop was chewy and looked like it was trailing turds.We shared two desserts and they were both outstanding.  The crema catalana was a custard flavored with lemon peel, cinnamon, and vanilla, with a caramelized top.  It tasted like a creme brulee with a lighter middle and a little bit of spice.  It was delicious.  The crema de chocolate a la sevillana was a chocolate dessert flavored with freshly grated orange and orange liqueur.  It was rich and dense but not overwhelming, a chocolate bonanza fit for any adult.I like tapas and Navarro's was a lovely place.  The food wasn't dazzling, and I've had much better tapas in the States, but I enjoyed my dinner.  I'd recommend it for a nice, low-key meal, preferably with good company.

fS03DvTWqdHtwhnLeBXf_w.text: Overall, this place is just OK. The decor was adorable, but the food left something to be desired. The meatballs were overcooked and not tasty. The 'jumbo prawns' weren't all that jumbo and were a little tough. Patatas Bravas were in a tomato sauce and weren't crisp at all. And no aioli. Hmm I was scratching my head a bit. The rose was delicious (Muga) as was the goat cheese with the caramelized onions. Same goes for chorizo. So overall, OK but not great.

O5ZrNDOXfyKmT3FI0xsxUw.text: First of all, the staff is Spanish. You KNOW it's going to be authentic when that's the case. Cosy Spanish interior with flamenco music playing in the background made you feel like you were eating at your abuela's. Got a bottle of house red, bread, and 4 tapas and that was deliciously sufficient for the two of us. Not a bad value either! Definitely hit the spot.

nEiIhFjNajwoSlj2mTV2fA.text: If you love Spain,esp the East coast,you will love Navarros. The food is quite simply the best Spanish tapas to be found anywhere in London.It has a magical interior with tiled walls, & handpainted chairs & tables:gorgeous! Once you have eaten the best food ever,you can even buy some of their ceramics too at really reasonable prices.I am a neighbour of nearly 50 years & when friends are in town they alwayssay please, lets go to Navarros (warning: you have to book, or you maybe disappointed : it is very popular)

photos.caption: Photo of Navarro's Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Two of the lovely ceramics for sale
Photo of Navarro's Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Navarro's Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

VOPThLRpJ0m_cb4NbvOxCQ.text: Small and charming with a robust tapas menu, Navarro's was a terrific place to grab a bite to eat.I enjoyed the shirmp and eel in sizzling oil and the padron peppers.  Both were very good but the shrimp and eel was extra tasty.  The shrimp are small but the eel is what you're there to try and it's very good.  If you see if on the menu--do give it a try!Service was friendly and despite it being very crowded the attendants did their level best to take my order and deliver dishes quickly. They maaaay want to consider adding another server in the future if crowds are like that every night.Keep up the great work Navarro's!

Rn3JfIPUS_8bShVoqQQTaQ.text: Navarros is an excellent, small Andalucian Tapas restaurant at the top of Charlotte Street.  There are a few Tapas places round here and if Spanish is your thing you really are spoilt for choice, Barrica, Salt Yard, Fino, Navarros etc.  Navarros holds its own though, it looks tiny from the outside but there is a downstairs as well, nicely decorated with traditional Andalucian tiles.  The staff are friendly and generally Spanish.They have a decent wine list and even have a "special" wine list on request that has some rare and expensive treats.The food is very good and each dish is a decent size portion.  Between 2 of us we had 7 dishes and I cant remember the last time I was that full!  Especially good were the meat brochettes, dangling skewers of chicken or pork. served with a plate of saute potatoes underneath.  They also do special potato bombe which is like a fried ball of potato covered in aioli, which was nice - if you like your garlic strong!  Then as always theres the Jamon, which is very good.Its not a cheap meal out but the food is good, the staff are nice and the surroundings make you feel like you could be in Spain.

2f_5RNeSvPz17hO3kC42tg.text: Takes reservations! For a tapas restaurant in Soho, that is quite impressive already. To be fair, it's been a while since I've been to Navarro's, but I can't say that there was much that stood out about the food to make me come back for anything other than the convenience of it. One of the more impressive dishes was a meat skewer but that was for the presentation of it!

29Qi2GbDwXPNfv-A6Nx4lw.text: This is a nice place and is bigger than it looks as you head downstairs into a very large restaurant.  Despite the fact they lost our reservation (boo) we were able to get a table.  I love the old-school Spanish tiles on the wall.  As my Spanish friend said it feels like you are in Madrid.  The tapas were good.  I didn't think they were exceptional but they definitely honored traditional Spanish tapas.  It is a nice place to go with a group for a relaxing and enjoyable lunch or dinner.

P_2x6Wte7Ouq8KAOjMT4EA.text: Stunningly delicious food. I had gorgeous cod in a tomato sauce, spinach rissoles and a lentil stew all of which were gobsmackingly good. My other half had the best rosemary potatoes I have ever tasted. The staff were very friendly and efficient, the decor was spot on (the basement looked even better than the main dinning area which is unheard of) and the wine delicious. Best tapas I have ever been too. Leaves all the others standing. Will will return again and again. In fact I can't wait  I'm off ;-)Josh Ward Josh Ward Garden Designhttp://www.joshwardgardendesign.com

nsNaeye_1j1fWwx4dYhwDQ.text: Stunningly delicious food. I had gorgeous cod in a tomato sauce, spinach rissoles and a lentil stew all of which were gobsmackingly good. My other half had the best rosemary potatoes I have ever tasted. The staff were very friendly and efficient, the decor was spot on (the basement looked even better than the main dinning area which is unheard of) and the wine delicious. Best tapas I have ever been too. Leaves all the others standing. Will will return again and again. In fact I can't wait ...... I'm off ;-)Josh Ward joshwardgardendesign.com

Rpd2SJTz-Kj0S-UlQyldJw.text: I've eaten at this place twice. What I like about this place is the breadth and depth of offerings they have. Veggie, seafood, meat, etc. They are all pretty damn solid too, so hard to go wrong.Their dessert's leave much to be desired though.Also, not sure if it's just me -- but I find their chairs to be very uncomfortable.

4nfyvqERWjcq9sKL2_144w.text: Although, this place is super cute with such a great atmosphere and great service, I wasn't so impressed with the food they served us at my last visit...Me and my friend ordered  several different tapas - specials of the day - tuna salad with tangerine, grilled peppers - I'm not completely certain how these dishes were supposed to be special, since they surprised us with tinned tuna. I still keep thinking tinned tuna? How dare they charge me almost £6 for tinned tuna and some iceberg salad? Not impressive at all! The other dish of grilled peppers, where better, but not good - cold, really cold grilled peppers in water instead of sauce... It wasn't impressive either! I know 90's is back in fashion, but I never knew it would include the cuisine...Other tapas was called something like honey lamb, but sadly my imagination got too wild there.. I expected chunks of lamb covered in herbs and honey.. But what landed on our table was more like a magic of school cuisine... There were lentils as well... Maybe I should not mention those...Plus side was grilled goat cheese, raisins and seeds. It was heaven! sweet, sticky, tangy, smooth, distinct soft goat cheese taste. Absolutely mind blowing! Also the reason for three stars instead of two.

4M_3zEUecw43FZkzRKYpuA.text: Quick glance:+ attentive and friendly staff+ really delicious and fresh tapas+ good selection of tapas for everyone+ good selection of wine at decent prices+ value for money- does not have a bar area for waiting- one table sits right by the doors of ladies & gentsFull review:I went with two friends on a Thursday night. We arrived at the restaurant at about 7pm and it was fully booked. Thankfully for us, there was a table of hurried diners who were keen to leave fairly soon, so the lady behind the counter said she would call us as soon as the table frees up, while we go out for a round of drinks nearby. (The restaurant does not have a bar area).True to her words, she rang about 15 minutes after and it took us awhile to get from the bar but she warmly welcomed us when we returned to the restaurant. This gives you a good idea of their superb service all around the restaurant. The waitresses were also very friendly and attentive. We had two bottles of wine (it was called Navarra and it was pleasant) and six dishes amongst us, with some bread and olive. It was more than enough food and everything was delicious. I would recommend the pulpo (octopus) which was very fresh and the Iberico loin of pork which looked like beef in colour and tasted amazing. The bill (bread and olives, two bottles of wine, 6 tapas dishes, and tips) came out to £30 per head. I highly recommend this restaurant for its authentic taste, warm atmosphere, and good value.

0y5Ji5TM6X563rcxiPOCHg.text: This Spanish restaurant/tapas bar has been around for ages and never disappoints. I particularly like the way the menu is laid out in columns for veggie, seafood and meat options. Everything I have ever eaten here has been delicious.The staff are friendly and looked particularly lovely today. The restaurant has recently been refurbished (new wooden floors) and the photographer was in to take some pix for the website - I'll be checking regularly :-)I mainly come for lunches, but Navarro's is also very popular for birthday parties, etc. Can get a bit noisy, especially in the basement.Does anyone buy the kitsch ceramics on sale in the shop?

86wcvDChRxjCSQ6VD8XOZQ.text: Classical and cosy the Andalusian tapas restaurant is the best Spanish restaurant I've been too. I treated my friend here for getting herself and job. The women dressed in burning red Flamenco dresses with single blood red rose in their tightly combed dark hair were a classic brand feature of the restaurant.The menu is fabulous and tasty, and the wine selection too good to be true. They have a fabulous decor at the entrance which I like; its not like your walking into the dining section. But this display which works like a reception too is done very cleverly.My friend was happy and so was I at the end of a perfect celebration.

photos.caption: Photo of Navarro's Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. main dining space
Photo of Navarro's Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Entrance foyer
Photo of Navarro's Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Entrance

syYTRwOst5ZNwDVmmeuMcg.text: A fantastic little Tapas Bar!From the street this place looks quite small but there's seating downstairs as well.We went quite late on a Friday and were looked after by amazingly friendly staff.The food and wine selection is quite comprehensive, and really tasty. I'd recommend the patatas bombas - very tasty!

QRVsSOzOz_TRDHARuEOCUg.text: I had a chicken breast with some mashed potatoes and salad. It was one of the best meals I have ever had

19G0W4ZYTqbifSfmybiQ-A.text: I came here because my friends couldn't stop talking about it.The decor and setup of the restaurant is cosy and authentic, though perhaps a little too much, making it just a bit messy and confusing.  While running downstairs in a rather hidden staircase to find my table without a server/maitre'd leading the way, and imagining that I can speak Spanish as I order (because my server hardly understood when i just read out the English description of the foods) may have been fun and new to me, asking for things like tap water and my pitcher of sangria to be less sweet and fizzy, not to mention why it's fizzy, had proven to be hectic and tiring.The food was alright.  My friend and I shared 8 tapas and generally they were all quite oily, though the flavours are as good as we expected.  I can hardly remember what I had but I definitely recall wanting to go back to Barcelona right the way to eat some tapas so good that I'd still dream about exactly how I felt when i ate there a year ago.I wouldn't mind going back, but I don't think I'd voluntarily want to spend another 30pounds per head at this place again.

1LPpr3ndd9JhyT0KFQsHeQ.text: As you walk in, you will be transported to Spain no doubt. I have been to Navarro's a few times and I probably sampled pretty much everything on the menu. The portions are huge and each time I felt beyond full. Try the sangria and if unsure just go with the classics like calamaris, patatas bravas, gambas, tortilla espanola, jamon, chorizo etc ... or maybe try the set menu if there's too much to chose from. Very rustic but that's the charm of it all!

lVp05vIIPYbNPgGNFaUWVg.text: Do not go! Food: Flavorless, greasy, and old. Boquerones are not fresh like in many places but these ones are not even a good canTortilla is pre-made so they microwave it and it's super dryPulpo a la gallega, bad potato quality Lamb skewer - I rather eating one of those a kebab from the street that people eat when they are drunk Service: Terrible, bad mood from the waitress Never ask you if you need anything You ask questions and they get annoyed Is not a happy environment Is not fare that the owner allows such a mediocre restaurant offering "Spanish food" with this quality, and charging similar prices as the other Spanish restaurants around. I bet he is not even Spanish. People be careful take care of your money and time. Spaniards, don't let these restaurant sell your food pretending they are Spanish!

lWnNhoUlvPyLD2Mml5xfyA.text: Cute tapas restaurant featuring good execution on classic dishes mixed with local innovations.  Excellent friendly service, good wine and spirit selection. Reasonable prices.   Worth a visit for sure

ipEpWw5jmEKnq2OMDKDlwQ.text: OMG, so good. Reminded me of time in Spain. Excellent food and service. Highly recommend the Chocolat Sevillana and Crema d's Catalan.

Kx44jPoqa6MD_WJrmgHBcg.text: Price of course depends on you.  it can get slightly but not greatly spendy.  the quality seems slightly lower than 10 years ago or more, but still 4+ star.  a go to place for us. you can get to spain while in England. I can state, that if you ate here 4 times and did not like it, then you do not like tapas. If you eat here once, you might just not like that dish. the dishes that I do like are great, so the dishes I dont' like I assume are just dishes I don't like, and that they came out the way they were supposed to.

gxQfGH6wBntW-bETepjyMg.text: With a subtle Spanish feel, a homely essence and a quaint decor throughout the restaurant, Navarro's can provide a pleasant Spanish dining experience from the centre of London. There is a good number of seating both on the ground and basement levels and the even the toilets have been given a good touch of attention (including a cute pig dispenser in the ladies). The table is set with a small bouquet of beautifully arranged flowers, china personalised to the restaurant and green napkins to give another hint of originality.Unfortunately there are not many options for refreshing cold beverages e.g. no fruit cocktails our fresh juices but there is an extensive wine list. The food menu on the other hand is full of great choices from a 'special tapas menu' to a whole page full of vegetarian options, a page full of seafood tapas and a page full of meat dishes. The food is well presented and humble; not over-the-top in flavour or prices yet is made up of decent ingredients. The scallop and chorizo skewers (part of their special tapas range) was of a decent size but the chorizo was a little tough and the scallop a little bland. The Espinacas Con Garbanzos with spinach, chickpeas and croutons is deliciously flavoured, a unique mixture of textures and sumptuously soft. The Pulpo Salteado Con Pure De Papas Alinas has well cooked octopus mixed with spring onion potato puree; a decent filler to the meal. The Brocheta De Cordero Con Patatas A Lo Pobre was probably the best tapas amongst my evening's choice of 4; serving up a well seasoned and cooked long lamb skewer dangling proudly over some fragrant rosemary potatoes with garlic and onions. As for desserts, the Crema Catalana is basically a glorified Creme Brulee and the Churros Con Chocolate were a delight with the churros served hot, delicately crispy and generously sprinkled with sugar plus accompanied with a separate heated chocolate dip.In conclusion, Navarro's achieves in creating a hospitable environment, a subtle Spanish flair and an intriguing and vast food selection. This humble establishment on Charlotte Street is brimming with potential and already delivers many a treat; thus I hope to return for more in due time.

photos.caption: Photo of Navarro's Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Pig soap dispenser
Photo of Navarro's Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. CHURROS CON CHOCOLATE sprinkled with sugar and served with a thick, Spanish hot chocolate dip
Photo of Navarro's Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. CREMA CATALANA 4.95  Delicious custard, flavoured with lemon peel, cinnamon and vanilla, caramelized on top

Jj5ddBncOgzcr8WqgHI1pQ.text: First visit... I was looking for a good spot for Spanish food. I am always a bit skeptical about tapas bar. They usually screw you for a lot of money and bad Spanish jamon iberico. But that one was highly recommended on yelp. And a good friend of mine from Paris was in London for the night. So let s go!When you step a foot in that rather small and cosy restaurant you immediately know you are somewhere in Spain. Traditional and a bit old fashioned atmosphere, all the decoration stuffs I used to see when I spent holidays some time in remote places in Spain. This is very welcoming though!Then a look at menu. It s really hard to make a choice as everything looks so yummy. We finally decided to take a few dishes and share them. We had the croquetas, the calamares Fritos, pork and mashed potatoes and the lentajes con chorizo. Everything was delicious... Well cooked. The lentejas were maybe a bit salty. But I felt like I wanted to have one or two more. But it was not reasonable so I decided to have a dessert  i took the churros con chocolate... It reminded my childhood when I had churros during my holidays in Portugal. So fucking great! They came with a small jug of melted chocolate! Wow!This was overall a really good experience and I would recommend anyone to make a stop there.  Waiteresses have been very nice and helpful. The value for money is also very good. So if you guys wanna have a bit of Spain without taking too much money from your bank account, go to Charlotte street and stop by navarro's.We tried the Rioja 2012 red wine they sell by the glass. It was decent but nothing breath taking I am afraid. I think it  is worth going again and try another one

photos.caption: Photo of Navarro's Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. pork and mashed potatoes / croquetas... everything was really good!
Photo of Navarro's Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. calamares Fritos!
Photo of Navarro's Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. these churros are just great! And they come with real melted chocolate... yummy!

MjfhxwkLs2Cbrw9PCzvbkA.text: I  loved the feel of this place when I walked in as they've really captured a little slice of Spain with the decor and you almost feel like you could be in the Mediterranean once you step inside - if you're far away from the window that is!There was a wide variety of tapas choice on the menu and coming from a half Spanish background with PLENTY of experience eating at countless tapas bars in Madrid, I have to say these were pretty tasty, well-portioned tapas and some of the better ones I've tasted in London.The only thing that put a slight dampener on the experience was the service. They captured the Spanish vibe in the decor and the food, but not so much in the less-than-friendly service which was a shame.

OmlMSWjtI_S6qlYgorlSiw.text: Let me preface this with the fact that I was born and raised in Spain and all my family is from the Basque country (Hondarribia\Bilbao\San Sebastian) so I have a point of reference here. I was excited when I found this on my recent search of restaurants in London and I was pretty excited when I saw the menu. Too bad I was in for an unpleasant surprise. Walking in you see its a small place and some of the servers are definitely from Spain so that's good. Looking at the menu I am thinking ok this is going to be good. Was it? No way. It was basically borderline bad. So for starters it took forever to get service, like 15 minutes just to get to order water. Second, if you want bread which is served automatically everywhere in Spain you gotta order and pay for it. Every other restaurant in London so far just brought us bread and many were not pricey either. So whatever lets order and see what happens. So we order 4 dishes and I expect them to arrive together. They don't and they are mostly spread pretty far apart.Dish 1 - Fried chorizo in Cognac. So in Spain when I order chorizo it shows up as long strips that are fried and then drained. This showed up sliced thin in a red pool of grease. No bread, no nothing with it. Just a spoon, and a whole lot of grease. Its not appetizing and it didnt taste very good this way. It was heavy and kinda gross. If i had other food to balance it with perhaps it would be better but why slice it and serve it in an inch of grease. Epic Fail.Dish 2. Iberico croquetas with god knows what. It was just weird. For those who know how it should be, its a bechamel that is thickened and flavored usually with cheese, ham or cod in my experience (and how my mom makes them). They should be fluffy and crisp with the inside creamy. These were some funny texture and color, being grayish and the taste was just off. I dont know who came up with this recipe but they should throw it out. Fail #2.Dish 3. Potato croquetas with Chorizo, Sounds good right? Well not terrible, the texture what more what I expected but it was pretty bland and had very little chorizo. What I did find was chopped into squares much to large and they probably need to revisit the balance and construction of this recipe. As a cook, yes I can fix this dish. Salt, pepper, maybe some garlic and use a soft chorizo to blend it up. This had potential and may have been the best thing we had which wasn't saying much. Dish 4. Bacalao, or Salt Cod in a tomato sauce with peppers and onions if I recall. The cod was served skin on which I would have preferred removed. it was barely warm and bland, and I am thinking that this was reheated. Something about the dish wasn't striking me as legit here. The dish in all was luke-warm and the fish thin and skimpy. Fail #3.So in summary, we had a disjointed meal served at long intervals with mediocre food and inconsistent service. The girls are very nice, the place is cute but this place needs a service and food smack-down to get it back on track. I dont consider this a good Spanish restaurant and it certainly wasn't cheap by Spanish standards either. The reviews here are either people who got food on a good day or dont really care what they eat. I dunno. All I can say is our meal was expensive and quite bad. Agur.

YNk9PKz1iPm6z50UAGO0dQ.text: We had:CALAMARES FRITOSBACALAO A LA ROTEÑA ARROZ CREMOSO CON GAMBASCHORIZO PICANTE AL CONAC PULPO SALTEADO CON PURÉ DE PAPAS ALIÑAS PATATAS BRAVASNavarros is a nice litle family restaurant just off Charlotte Street. The front is a shop selling all sorts of nice Spanish food. The interior isn't super modern or trendy-more down to earth rustic.We came on a Saturday night and the place was reasonably busy. Service was friendly and helpful. On the wine front I wanted red despite ordering mainly fish so wanted a light wine. I was recommended a wine from Jumilla which was only a couple of quid over what I was going to order-it was really good.The lowdown on the food as follows:The calamari was very nice-crisp and tender, not chewy.The cod (Bacalao) was also great-large fillets of cod in a tasty, piquant sauce.The rice was creamy and very rich but tasty.The chorizo supposedly cooked in cognac was..meh! It was essentially a dish of sliced chorizo-not horrible by any stretch but you could not taste the brandy and it was too plain. Some of the pieces were a little burnt.The octopus (pulpo..) was again not my favourite. I wanted large chunks of octopus cooked in a rich sauce. This was slices of octopus on top of creamed spring onion puree. The octopus was lost in the overall taste, which was too similar to the creamed rice. Far from horrid but a slight disappointment.Overall, Navarros is a perfectly pleasant restaurant serving good tapas. Some dishes don't hit the high spot but that may be typical of such places.Oh.. and the patatas bravas were vey good. Loved them!

photos.caption: Photo of Navarro's Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Octopus
Photo of Navarro's Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Calamari
Photo of Navarro's Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Brilliant patatas bravas

ukNr4arSY1SYnobwN-yLaA.text: Its nice but fails to meet the mark. The tuna was tinned and slapped onto a bed of lettuce.... better description would be nice. The manchengo cheese was good, but there was also confusion as to the cheese plate substitution.. as some of us don't like blue cheese. the lentils were tasty but nothing to write home about.... overal, it was ok but nothing too special. nothing blew my mind or made me want to return any time soon.

J1ogOWUDd9vQG6szHHr88w.text: This tapas joint was quite nice! I visited with my mother in law and a friend. We were sent to sit downstairs in the basement which was cozy, romantic and nicely decorated. We ordered the squid, olives, bread basket, albondigas and charcuterie plate, all excellent! We each had glasses of wine, ordered the small but were a generous pour. The meatballs were so tender and some of the best we've ever had. Definitely recommended!

uwLfJREVDCl5zLdUee3CbQ.text: When I arrived here to meet my friend and his wife, the first thing they said was "oh, this wasn't the place we thought we were taking you!"  It turned out to be a happy accident, as this was a very cute and cozy tapas place with delicious food and nice atmosphere.I tend to think of all tapas restaurants as having the same menu: patatas bravas, chorizo, Serrano ham and Manchego cheese, croquettes... stop me if you've heard this before. This must mean that most people have a binary perception of tapas, they either love it or hate it, and among us tapas lovers any specific restaurant comes down to whether the food is actually cooked properly, plus the service and ambiance.  In this case, the service was quite friendly and the atmosphere very nice, being a rather small place with a homey feel.  The food was indeed well-prepared and delicious, so the entire experience was very pleasant.  If you're on the love side of my love/hate tapas dialectic, you should seek this place out, you won't be disappointed.

RXoCHqmbiYSfCPh_oqk5rA.text: This place was fantastic. I worry about adding to the many highly positive posts about this place... Maybe it becomes so popular I can't even get a reservation someday?The flavors of the four dishes I tried were all subtle. I would have added more garlic and a bit more chili on some, but I'm being really picky. It was all a rare, lovely treat. Not only will I return, but I want to bring everyone I care about to this place. The service was quite good, and the prices were very reasonable for this area.  Note that gratuity is included in the bill, but frankly if you double tip it's no loss since the service was really above par.Oh, and the decor was great.  Lots of colorful, Spanish tile. The place was nicely decorated - better than many restaurants.

rb8rBNkv10ElQhYPlxiR-A.text: Slunk into Navarro's one evening when looking for something different in the Goodge st area. There's quite a bit of overpricing in that locale, so did a bit of Yelpage on the hop - Navarro's was one of the best Yelped establishments, and, as it turned out, deservedly so.First off, we had a little trouble getting a table, on a Wednesday evening, but they squeezed us in. It appears a smallish place, but they have a large downstairs area. The place is done out in a authentically, with Spanish tiles and crockery.They serve tapas as well as some main meals and the usual appetizers of bread, olives, cheese and cured meats that you would expect.We ordered 5 tapas between two, which turned out to be a feast. The portions are ample indeed, and just incredibly good. Really delicious authentic dishes, served in an informal atmosphere. Gets a little noisy down there, so book with care if you plan on a private tete-a-tete.The honeyed lamb and scallops were a treat, the lentil stew is heart fayre. Can't wait to go back to this place.

Dm30JHSs2livrQ9sW_j1YA.text: Si! Si! Si!There are a plethora of 'tapas' restaurants in London these days, and many serve pretty much the same old menu.  At Navarro's you'll find a more authentic experience in many ways.  And the cost is quite fair for the high quality served. First, the staff are Spanish. The decor is very rustica-type -- with wooden chairs & tables, and lots of blue ceramics dotting the walls & shelves.  I went here with a few friends and so enjoyed many dishes, but a few stood out:-Pulpo: (octopus) Easy to get wrong.  Not so here. It was delicious; soft without being chewy, tasting fairly fresh and flavourful.-Lamb: (according to my friend): Succulent, flavoured with rosemary -- my foodie friends were blown away by it.-Calamares: Yes a typical dish, but done very well. Very light batter, crispy on the outside, also soft but not too chewy on the inside.-Poblano peppers: I haven't found these often in London tapas restaurants, although they are usually on the menu in Spain. These peppers have the distinct feature of being randomly hot; that is, within a given batch, you might get 20% which are chili hot, the others taste more like a slightly spicier green pepper. Fried and yummy, my friends hadn't had these before and really liked them. Big lovely servings, obliging staff, and a comfortable atmosphere.  Me gusta!

GscsttPAIetAyAXRey6xUg.text: Great Spanish place with excellent value. I came with two friends and of course, we ordered some tapas, a bottle of wine and a couple of starters. Pretty standard combination but executed really well. The restaurant is nicely designed and the food is rich and comes in decent portions. They also have a seasonal menu with some specials which are also worth checking.

0fPY6RWeaWQ6xdLhkLwfRw.text: Really happy with tasty meal, flexible menu options and friendly waitress!Good vegetarian choices too!

vdJbRyt8nB8DS-f_xUvNJA.text: I have to admit to being very disappointed about this place, especially seeing the fantastic reviews it gets on Yelp.  It was tapas restaurant no 3 in a weekend of tapas so maybe that was part of the problem but I felt the food was a let down and so was the service.We ordered patatas bravas, Chorizo, Gambos, croquetas and Berenjenas Gratinadas, which are aubergines stuffed with vegetables and topped with a cheese gratin.  This last item was particularly disappointing having loved it when I had it before but really disliking this version.We got our food quickly enough but our waitress spoke no English and couldn't understand when we asked her for anything outside of the menu.  We eventually gave up and left quickly, not even bothering with a coffee at the end.I won't be rushing back!

5qqFu_EmH3gd9DB6AIUaiQ.text: Went here with a group of friends on Valentine's Day for the first time (yes, we are quite the trolls). Restaurant was all decorated on the special day with heart and rose confetti sprinkled over the dinner table. Even the waitresses were all decked up and pretty.Three words I have for this restaurant: LOVE THE BREAD AND DIP. (oh wait, five words already)  That dip with the garlic.... heaven! (what's it called again? aleo oli? - it's OK that we all got garlic breath later) We refilled 3-4 bread baskets (among the 6 of us) and 2-3 dip saucers because it was that awesome - felt like I could survive on that bread+dip alone. Moving on to tapas: everything was delicious! You cannot go wrong. My favourite was ultimately the calamari. The fried skin was crunchy and the squid was soft and chewy - calamari like I've never tasted before. The wine list was reasonable for us students and we ordered a bottle for six. The waitress's recommendation was spot-on and we really enjoyed the wine with the food. Did I mention the staff were pleasant? Overall, loved the place. The interior was adorable and reminded me a little of Gaudi, while the price was reasonable. Amazing food at affordable prices. What's not to love?
